turn.text: Even though originally he had only a narrow indictment and he said “if you do not plead to his one I am going to get a broader one?”

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: As I stated in my brief, I believe that there is a distinct possibility that under McCree Brady v. United States where you noted that cognizable claim would be generated by a threat of additional prosecutions, that indeed it may very well be that in this circumstance you would have a coerced guilty plea.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if this situation had resulted in a guilty plea, the claim of coercion would still have been open?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: It would still be open, Your Honor.
That is true and a counsel may or may not have been sufficient to cut that coercion off.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In one district recently a study showed that there were great many cases where additional crimes were committed while the defendant was released on his own recognizance.
Six different charges ultimately had accumulated by the time they came to trial on the first one.
Would all that you have been saying apply equally to subsequent crimes committed repeatedly after the defendant was released on bail?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Why not?
The charge is still there.

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: I think the Sixth Circuit addressed this quite clearly and perhaps it has been a mistake on my part to not point this out, but always, the prosecutor is allowed, as under your decisions in Blackledge and North Carolina v. Pearce to demonstrate changes that account for why he did not obtain the original indictment.
In the case you have given me, the hypothetical, he would not have been able to originally indict on those charges.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: He might have been able to get the indictments on the other charges before they reach the point of plea negotiations?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: That would be perfectly acceptable because the original indictment could not have anticipated the subsequent conduct like your U.S. v. Paige analogy in North Carolina v. Pearce.
The one point I would make ultimately is that in Brady v. United States, Mr. Justice White, you stated.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The Court did?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: I am sorry, that is correct.

The statement was, in Brady, we find no threats being made between the time the man initially pled not guilty and he changed his plea to guilty, no threats being made to him in a face-to-face confrontation with the authorities.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I ask you if you would have a different position if there had never been any bargaining confrontations between the prosecutor and the defendant?
Simply, initially, there was an indictment.
No plea of guilty was forthcoming.
The prosecutor added a count.
He broadened the indictment.
No plea of guilty was forthcoming, and he kept broadening it.
Then they went to trial.
Would you be here then or not?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, because of what we asked for in a way of the prophylactic rule where the Sixth Circuit recognized that there would be an apprehension generated in --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So the face-to-face confrontation and the oral threat as you call it, really is not determinative in the case?

turn.speaker: j_vincent_aprile_ii
turn.label: Mr. J. Vincent Aprile, II
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, it is determinative in two ways.
I say that if we did not have the face-to-face threat stated here, we would not have actual vindictiveness and we would only be able to succeed on our relief under the prophylactic rule.
But I say we have actual vindictiveness so even without the prophylactic rule we can succeed.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
